runs.text: Display
Display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Review the following spellings and words: ai (train), ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Blend Words
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
Write
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Say
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell
Spell the word as you point to each letter.
Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Read
Then have students chorally read the word.
Write
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Point out the irregular spelling of to. Connect to to the words do and who.
Spelling Booster (10 MIN.)
Use More Dictation

Dictate the following words for students to spell: pay, play, rain, train, save, great. Write the words on the board for students to self-correct. Note on each students Student Observation Form sound-spellings they struggle with. Include more words with these sound-spellings in upcoming lessons.
Teach

Write the word hope. Write or use Phonics/Syllable Cards for suffixes -ful and -less. Read each one and have students repeat. Explain that a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the words meaning and sometimes its part of speech.
Model

Add -ful and -less to hope, one at a time. Model how to read the new words formed. Explain that -ful means full of, so hopeful means full of hope, and -less means no or without, so hopeless means without hope.
Practice
Continue by adding -ful and -less to these words: play (-ful), pain (-ful), rest (-less), help (-less). Guide students to read the words and determine the new words meaning.
Display
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Place the sorting cards ay and ai in a pocket chart.
Model/Sort
Model how to sort the words rain and say under the correct category card.
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
Chorally Respond
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Discuss Observations
Ask students what they notice about the words.
If necessary, point out that ai spelling never appears at the end of a word or syllable, but the ay spelling can.
Encourage students to look for words with ai and ay while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.
Vocabulary Booster (10 MIN.)
Read Aloud: Natures Crafty Color Changers
Display the photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the Read-Aloud prompts to highlight the words deliberately, accurate, transparent, pigments, and appealing, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display
Display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Review the following spellings and words: ai (train), ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Write
Have students write each long a spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /a/ sound each time they write the spelling.
Blend Words

Use the new blending words to apply the skill. For the first time through, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Say

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Read
Then have students chorally read the word.
Write
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Build Words Booster (10 MIN.)
Build More Words
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
Display
Display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Review the following spellings and words: ai (train), ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Write
Have students write each long a spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /a/ sound each time they write the spelling.
Blend Words

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud. Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then reblending the word together.
Say
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time.
Point to and say each word, having students repeat after you.
Spell
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Read
Then have students chorally read the word.
Write
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
High-Frequency Words Booster (10 MIN.)
Read, Build, Write: he, like, little, no, of, saw, this, to, we, with

Display the word cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., I saw a ____).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.
Display
Display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Review the following spellings and words: ai (train), ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Write
Have students write each long a spelling several times on paper or dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /a/ sound each time they write the spelling.
Blend Words
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with ea. Then have them put a box around all the words with -ful or -less.
Blending Focus
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
man, main, rain, chain
mad, may, say, stay
pan, pain, painful, painless (transition to multisyllabic)
State the Letter Card to change. For example, say:
Make man. Add the letter i after a to make the long a spelling. What word did you make?
Word Awareness Focus
Repeat, but dont tell students which letter to change. For example, say:
Change man to main
Vocabulary Booster (10 MIN.)
Read Aloud: Vernal PoolsShort-Lived Springtime Habitats
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words shallow, multitudes, vibrant, recedes, and exposed, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display
Display the Sound-Spelling Card long a. Review the following spellings and words: ai (train), ay (play), a_e (save), ea (break), a (apron).
Blend Words
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
Write
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Revisit the sentences to model sentence expanding by adding details. Have students expand one of their sentences.
Vocabulary Booster (10 MIN.)
Read Aloud: The Hottest Places on Earth
Display the photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words exceeds, inhospitable, radiates, and lethal, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Review

Use Phonics/Syllable Cards to model how to add suffixes to the following words: pain (-ful), pain (-less), paint (-er). Guide students to read the word and discuss its meaning based on the suffix added.
Build
Have students add -ful, -less, or -er to the following words to see how many words they can make: play, use, help, work, thank, rest. List the words as they form them. Discuss their meanings.
Write
Have students select two of the words from the list and write sentences for them.
This word means the opposite of woman.
(man)
Change one letter in
man
to name something you use to cook in.
(pan)
Add one letter to
pan
to make a word that names what you feel when you hurt your leg.
(pain)
Change one letter in
pain
to name water falling from the sky.
(rain)
Add one letter to
rain
to name something you can travel in.
(train)
Change one letter in
train
to name what you use to think.
(brain)
